column1: Osteomyelitis is a bone infection that is caused by bacteria or other germs.
Bone infection is most often caused by bacteria.
When a person has osteomyelitis: - Bacteria or other germs may spread to a bone from infected skin, muscles, or tendons next to the bone.
In children, the long bones of the arms or legs are most often involved.

Symptoms may include the following: - Bone pain - Excessive sweating - Fever and chills - General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise) - Local swelling, redness, and warmth - Pain at the site of infection - Swelling of the ankles, feet, and legs
The health care provider will perform a physical examination and ask about the symptoms you're having.
Antibiotics are given to destroy the bacteria causing the infection: - You may receive more than one antibiotic at a time.
If there are problems with blood supply to the infected area, such as the foot, surgery to improve blood flow may be needed to get rid of the infection.
With treatment, the outcome for acute osteomyelitis is usually good.
Amputation may be needed, especially in people with diabetes or poor blood circulation.
The outlook for people with an infection of a prosthesis depends partly on: - The person's health - The type of infection - Whether the infected prosthesis can be safely removed
